page.title: 18Woodland Walk.Bentley Wood.
page.content: On the 29th.June 1985 a group from West Tytherley Primary School were taken through the wood by Ralph Whitlock,broadcaster and writer,and Roy Pitman,naturalist.Their estimate was that there were 8 to 10 million trees.We saw that these tended to be beech in the northern chalky part and oak on the mixed soils to the south. Nurse crops of conifers,planted when The Forestry Commission managed the wood,needed to be removed.A nature trail was newly made with nest boxes including one for kestrels.We found spotted and butterfly orchids.There were prints and tracks of badgers,deer and weasels.Insects were being studied with over 400species of moth found. Butterflies abound-the fritilaries and purple emperor.The area is designated one of special scientific interest. (see another page)
